blocks.text:
Example 12—If $ y = g(t) = 4x + 4x^{2} \cdot 1929  \cdot 2 + \ldots 

Let $ u = \frac{ du}{dx} = 4 + 8x $.

blocks.description: This equation relates the derivative of y with respect to x through the chain rule.

blocks.text:
Example 13—For a spring loaded governor (see Fig. 19).   
$ W = T + Q(V - \sqrt{R}) .$

blocks.caption: Fig. 19—Spring loaded Governor.
blocks.description: This figure illustrates a spring loaded governor, displaying the relationship between weight (W), tension (T), and other variables.

blocks.text: Where $ W $ = force to elang the spring in unit, $ T $ = tension in spring, $ W $ = weight of I ball, $ I $ = angular velocity, $ R $ = radius of path of balls, $ I = \frac{2}{3} \cdot 32 \cdot \frac{d}{dt}( . -0625) $.

blocks.latex:
W = T + Q \left( V - \sqrt{R} \right) 

If $ W $ and $ Q $ are the two unknowns, we must form two equations. By simple substitution.
blocks.description: This equation sets up a system relating the forces and tensions in the context of the spring governor.
This equation represents the derivative of tension with respect to time.

blocks.text:
We are told that $ dT = dQ $. We find that:

$ \frac{2}{3} \cdot 32 \cdot (4 + 2.64) \cdot (dT) = Q \cdots (W - \sqrt{R}) $.
